Love the SINGIN' routine by Kurt Brownin', but to be fair, that routine quotes from and is intended as a tribute to Mr. Kelly.

and Elke

Can't believe my LYIN EYES, but there is an APPL- hangin' from ISAAC ......
(violates his own law of motion).

Gene Kelly's SINGIN' IN THE RAIN is nice, but Kurt Brownin' s skating routine of the musical is my favourite.

Welcome back, John. Was MISSIN' you and your avatars.

Your post makes me wined how our economy was in such better shape in 1968, with unemployment levels below 4% and much more economic growth.

Because the minimum wage in 1968 was about $10.68 an hour in modern dollars, or $3.43 more per hour. That's about $7,000.00 a year in income on a forty hour work week.

I won't deny that higher minimum wages do not redistribute income from the top down. They do. And our overall economy is far better
for it. We've been starving the minimum wage for over thirty years.

Care to guess the impact starving the minimum wage has had on our economy?

My heart aches for these countries but:
I do not understand why our military & our citizens need to be THERE when the Africans themselves should be able to handle the containment efforts. Once again paternal American behavior. It's no wonder the continent is not self sufficient, The West takes care of their needs. I suggest that if you poll USA citizens and ask if they are willing to risk their own deaths and permit West Africans to come here and potentially infect us, you would find few affirmative answers. So why then is the President not temporarily suspending West Africans from entering this country?
The USA must protect our country, our people and our interests first. That is how it should be but obviously the administration again shows that our welfare comes last.

Actually standard deductions have gotten so high a relatively small percentage of homeowners are helped by the mortgage interest deduction. I don't know this for sure but I would venture the percentage of tax returns with a
schedule A has declined significantly over the last thirty years.

I love The Giving Tree. It is one of my all time favorite "children's" books. Ive never read it to any child - and Ive done that many times - without struggling to speak the final words. To each their own.

I've never read 'The Giving Tree' -- it was published well past my childhood -- but what struck me forcefully about the exchange was the startling difference between Anna Holmes and Rivka Gelchen. Gelchen's essay was shrewd, pertinent, elegant, and thoughtful; Holmes's was banal, juvenile, awkward, and predictable -- the difference between the pensees of Blaise Pascal and Oprah Winfrey

I always hated this story. I told my children and now grandchildren that the story is about a selfish narcissist (the boy) and a misguided caretaker (the tree). It is never enough to effect happiness for another without any reciprocation. Martyrdom just doesn't work. Nice to have some validation after all these years.

My Japanese wife was given this book by her female classmate when our youngest daughter was a few years old and dedicated it to her. I overlooked it until I used the book in our EFL class to children. As a father of two daughters in a conservative society, where I first encountered Japanese priorities for males at the preschool line up for the Thomas-train school bus, (the girls were always given the seats at the back, even if they were usually waiting for the boys to show up, I was disturbed by this message. Japanese girls are mysteriously ambitious in learning English, just look at the percentages of the top places in the English speech  contests, where their winning speeches are not about ambition, but about saving the wounded puppy.(Ok, a little poetical exaggeration; as my wife says,*Everything is changing.*  *Hmmph*, not fast enough in my opinion). I turned to the elementary school girls who were lapping up every word, and to the boys, because even this book was simple enough to follow it. *This is a book about your mother* I said, *not your father, though it could be.*

a kind of covoluted apology. too little too late. As some say this isn:t necessarily an endorsement of a lifestyle. but for children it seems to show what reality is like. It was a very popular book in my EFL children:s classroom.
INteresting. I would probably have the same take on the situation.

I think you have a point. Us males never had the thought that was what was going on in their minds. when I was going to an all male junior and senior high school, the subject of women/girls could,  with restrained understatement be described as *talking about raw meat.* Our thinking was so much like the guy in The Giving Tree, that it is personally beyond embarassing, toward *frightening*. How could my mother have raised me in such a way? And yet I was singularly devoted/dependent on her wishes...typing this has resusitated the confusion/astonishment of the disconnect. And I was not alone.

I think we are, but we shouldn't dwell on it or we will be given to paralysis. And we shouldn't reach for the rose colored glasses either. I dont know what the balance is because I have not found balance in much of any thing  in my life, yet. What we tend to do is look towards our children and imagine what we have done. I say imagine because we don't yet know. Ours haven't yet encountered a single thing about about their "self" which isn't cute and irresistable. this figment of my imaginatiion can depress me if I let it.

As a troll of the comments of this book, I think you are absolutely right and deserve more *likes* than you have received. I am home today with too much time, school was canceled in Tokyo for approaching typhoon.

And I see again how I was raised to be the man in the picture, and again I am depressed, and helpless to do as much as i wanted to do to change things, for at some point during that process I was dimly aware of what was being done to/for me, but I felt powerless. Now, reading and commenting here has stirred up those memories. I'm going to stop and leave now.
When I was about 5 I heard Oscar Wilde's "The Happy Prince" on a radio show, and I wept uncontrollably for about an hour. Same story, nu? Better told, of course.

Thank you - I hadn't thought about new shoots from the roots before. I still don't like it, but maybe I dislike it less.
But you're right about Hans Christian Anderson.
I hate the Giving Tree.  I don't understand why it is so loved.

Oh yes - rainbow fish. My son loves the rainbow fish (it was read to him in school). I edit it when I read it to him. When he's old enough to read the words I guess we can talk about which version he likes better, and why.
I hid the giving tree. It's even sadder than rainbow fish. But he was read that one in school too.
I believe you are right daun fallon.  It is a boy named Sue and as i write these words i can almost hear Johnny Cash singing that song.
I work for a company that services student debt. Business is booming.

This is my contention. We will get more college grads if college is harder, not easier, to get into. We won't get college ready students until we communicate what other countries in the world do: do well in high school or no college for you.

My contention is that well meaning people continue to sell the Community College option to kids (instead of making them work in High School) and this guarantees a continued stream of unprepared kids.

Community College should be repositioned as vocational and career enrichment, not college prep for the unready. And we should drastically scale it back.

I have proposed that tuition be raised and a significant proportion rebated to students who satisfactorily complete a course. This way, we can weed out dabblers or, at least, make them pay up for their lack of seriousness.

It's true that not everyone needs "advanced math", but yes everyone should understand high school math. The article even states that what these kids are struggling with is eighth or ninth grade math. Even trigonometry (cos(pi/2)) is high school math. How low do you people want to set the bar? We're trying to run a technologically advanced country and world here. Math is becoming more important, not less ....

It is quite obvious that Bernanke and Paulson lied about their inability to bailout Lehman. Similarly when they told us that the subprime crisis was "largely contained" they knew quite well that is was not. Bending the truth is their bizarre way of "calming the markets". The Fed is simply their to serve their masters on Wall Street. Leading the public astray with false statements is just part of the game.

What I am convinced happened in that fatal day was that the combination of the spineless apparatchiks that had fallen to regulatory capture was mixed with the ideological dogma of markets in the financial industry (that had grown over the past generation to exclude every other philosophy) ended up in the perfect storm.

The technical incompetence and ignorance of the regulators, the White House and Congress mixed with the willful moral blindness of the financial industry was always going to cause a crisis. The fact that Lehman Brothers was the first domino was just due to circumstance. The fact that it was a bubble in the residential credit market that was the Big One that popped was also a matter of circumstance. If they did not create the crisis something else would have come along.

The reality is that the financial industry in the U.S. has become too large, too interconnected and too cozy. TBTF is the product of having only a few large institutions that dominate the markets. The fact that are there are so few means that those the top of the pyramid are all buddy-buddy with each other and have a web of instruments that tie their balance sheets together. As soon as one encounters a problem, the whole system falls. And, because the entire U.S. economy has become so dependent on the financial industry, their corruption becomes the entire country's problem.

The only way to avoid another crisis to break apart the TBTF financial institutions. That's what RTCM did 20 years ago.
